fields.descriptive_line: Theatrical ensemble of robe, mantle, brooch and a pair of shoes worn by Henry Irving as King Lear, 1892, Act I, at the Lyceum under Irving's management.
fields.physical_description:
[mantle] Mantle; large mantle of same cream-coloured woollen fabric as S.2740:1-2010, with grey border, decorated with embroidery and applique-work, with the addition of brick-red and pale blue, in Celtic bird-forms (apparently inspired by the Book of Kells) set with turquoise-blue discs and small oval plaques of gilt metal.  Fabric gathered and tacked together on right shoulder, and held by brooch S.2740:3-2010.  The thickness of the material served to add strength and bulk, on his first entrance, to the actor's naturally spare figure.
[gown] Robe/Gown of cream-coloured woollen fabric, with ornament of embroidery and applique-work in pink cotton and orange wool, in bold circle and conventional flower design.  Closes at the front with 8 buttons. Underskirt of light cream colour edged with simple embroidery, slightly longer than over gown. Bell-shaped  half, over-sleeves, with weights at base to keep in place with longer close sleeves undersleeves (closing with draw string) set in.  The thickness of the material served to add strength and bulk, on his first entrance, to the actor's naturally spare figure. Mrs. Nettleship maker's label.
[brooch] Large penannular brooch of gilt metal fastening cloak (S.2740:2-2010) on the right shoulder.
[shoe] Ankle-high shoe of light brown leather, fastening with strap and button at the ankle. There are 9 pairs of eyelets but no evidence that the boots were evidence were ever laced. Ornamented with scrolls of couched braid and orange glass jewels.
[shoe] Ankle-high shoe of light brown leather, fastening with strap and button at the ankle. There are 9 pairs of eyelets but no evidence that the boots were evidence were ever laced. Ornamented with scrolls of couched braid and orange glass jewels (5 at toe and 1 at ankle, but evidence that one stone is missing from its setting).
fields.dimensions:
[mantle] Length: 186 cm
[gown] Length: 143 cm For outer gown. Back of neck to hem. Inner 'underskirt' (about 6 cms longer), Width: 50 cm Across Shoulders
[brooch] Diameter: 11 cm
[shoe] Height: 1.5 cm Heel, Length: 29.5 cm sole, Height: 12.5 cm from sole to top of heel
[shoe] Height: 1.5 cm Heel, Length: 29.5 cm Sole, Height: 12.5 cm Height from sole to top of heel
fields.materials_techniques:
[mantle] Wool, with embroidery and appliqué
[gown] Wool, with embroidery and appliqué; gilt metal
fields.public_access_description:
Henry Irving (1838-1905) wore this costume in the title role of Act I  of King Lear by William Shakespeare (1564-1616).  Lear is one of the most important parts to play for any tragic actor of high standing.  Irving had first discussed doing so in 1883 and eventually produced the play in 1892.  Accounts of his performance vary, but many who saw the opening night felt he had badly misjudged the vocal interpretation, his voice being weak and often inaudible.  Although he made adjustments to correct this, the dramatic criticism of the press was based on the first performance.  Despite this, King Lear ran for 76 performances, an unprecedented achievement at the time for a play which was not popular with audiences on account of its gloomy and depressing themes.

Irving became a professional actor in 1856, and learned his trade in regional theatres until 1866, when he came to London.  He joined the Lyceum Theatre company under the management of H. L. Bateman in 1871, winning great acclaim that year for his psychologically developed characterisation of the guilt-ridden inn-keeper Mathias in Leopold Lewis’s melodrama The Bells.  He took on the responsibilities of ‘actor-manager’ in 1878 when he assumed the management of the Lyceum, and remained there until 1902, enjoying star status with his leading lady Ellen Terry (1847-1928).   Irving produced a diverse range of old and new plays at the Lyceum, including Shakespeare, historical drama, and literary adaptations.  His tireless work to elevate the status of the theatrical profession was rewarded in 1895 when he became the first actor ever to receive a knighthood for services to the Theatre.

Irving specialised in spectacularly staged productions with large casts of performers. He commissioned designers and composers to create appropriate scenery, costume and incidental music, played by a full orchestra.  Although electric lighting was available from the 1880s, Irving preferred the softer effects of gas, with lime light to focus attention at key points in the play.  Irving toured complete productions outside London, taking the full company, scenery and costumes throughout the United Kingdom and across the United States and Canada.   The development of the railway system made his the first generation able to achieve this level of touring productions.
fields.bibliography: Holmes, Martin. <u>Stage Costumes and Accessories in the London Museum</u>. London : HMSO, 1968. Catalogue entry 141.
